Graphical abstract The hydrogenation of fatty acid (C17COOH) over the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst can be significantly enhanced by coupling with CO2, leading to a notable increase in the selectivity exceeding 99 % for fatty alcohol (C18OH). The hydrogenation of fatty acids to fatty alcohols, alongside the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, represents crucial pathways for addressing the depletion of fossil resources and achieving carbon neutrality. However, the catalytic conversion rates of these two reactions remain low under mild conditions. In this study, we discovered an innovative approach that couples stearic acid (C17COOH) hydrogenation with CO2 hydrogenation in a one-pot catalytic tandem process using the optimized CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst. This method significantly enhances the yields of methanol and fatty alcohol under mild reaction conditions of 200 °C, 3 MPa, 6 h, with a H2:CO2 ratio of 3:1. The reaction mechanism revealed that stearic acid methyl ester (C17COOCH3) acts as a key intermediate in the coupling process. Specifically, the in situ methanol produced from CO2 hydrogenation is converted by C17COOH into C17COOCH3, which is then hydrogenated to form stearic alcohol. This coupling reaction offers important insights for the simultaneous utilization of CO2 and biomass-derived fatty acids in producing value-added chemicals. Furthermore, our findings could inspire the design of more synergistically coupled catalytic reactions that leverage dual-promotional effects for the hydrogenation of CO2 and carboxylic acid compounds. This approach not only enhances the efficiency of these transformations but also aligns with the broader goals of sustainability and resource efficiency in chemical processes. Keywords Fatty acid hydrogenation Coupling reaction CO2 hydrogenation Dual promotion One-pot tandem catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass is the only renewable organic carbon resource in nature, and can be converted into the value-added fine chemicals through catalytic conversion route to partially replace or supplement the traditional fossil resource [1]. Among the various biomass conversion routes, chemical thermal catalysis is the first choice because of the unique advantages of high efficiency and easy implementation with present chemical infrastructure. Fatty alcohol (R-CH2OH), as an important fine chemical compound, is widely used in surfactants, cosmetics, and pharmaceutical fields [2,3]. R-CH2OH can be synthesized by catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reaction of biomass oils (Fig. 1 ) [4,5]. There are three HDO reaction pathways for the synthesis of R-CH2OH in industry [6]. The first pathway involves the direct hydrogenation of plant oils into fatty alcohols (Fig. 1, route 1). However, due to the high stability and steric hindrance of triglyceride molecules, this route often requires harsh reaction conditions, such as temperatures of 300–325 °C and hydrogen pressures exceeding 20 MPa. Additionally, under these severe conditions, glycerol, a by-product, is prone to further decomposition, generating unwanted by-products and resulting in glycerol waste, which limits the industrial viability of this route. The second pathway involves the hydrolysis of oils into free fatty acids, which are then hydrogenated to produce R-CH2OH (Fig. 1, route 2). This route also necessitates harsh conditions, including high temperatures (250–300 °C) and pressures (10–20 MPa). Moreover, the intermediate aliphatic aldehyde formed during this process is susceptible to decarbonylation, leading to the production of Cn−1 hydrocarbons and a loss of carbon atoms, which negatively affects the atomic economy of the reaction. Additionally, the corrosive nature of fatty acids can damage equipment, and the active sites of the catalyst may leach under acidic conditions, resulting in poor catalytic stability. To enable the reaction to proceed under milder conditions, fatty acids are first methylated with methanol to produce fatty acid methyl esters (R-COOCH3), which are then hydrogenated to produce fatty alcohols through a two-step process namely the third pathway. Specifically, the hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters and fatty acids both involve the initial hydrogenation of the methyl ester group to form an aldehyde, which is further hydrogenated to produce fatty alcohols. The aldehyde serves as a key intermediate in the hydrogenation of esters and fatty acids and is highly reactive, capable of being rapidly reduced to fatty alcohols [7] (Fig. 1, route 3). This strategy is advantageous because R-COOCH3 is thermodynamically easier to hydrogenate than fatty acids, facilitating the synthesis of fatty alcohols. The methylation of fatty acids or triglycerides requires methanol, which can be synthesized through the selective hydrogenation of the greenhouse gas CO2, and representing a promising carbon recycling technology that supports the goal of “carbon neutrality”. However, under fixed reaction conditions (e.g., 250–300 °C, total pressure of 2–5 MPa, H2: CO2 ratio of 3:1), the single-pass conversion rate of CO2 is quite low. Additionally, thermodynamic limitations create an equilibrium constraint for methanol yield [8]. According to Le Chatelier’s principle, the equilibrium conversion rate can be increased by removing the product from the reaction system, allowing the shifting of the reaction to the right side [9]. For example, in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, the immediate removal of methanol can thermodynamically shift the reaction equilibrium to favor product formation, thus enhancing the overall yield of methanol. This leads to the potential integration of fatty acids into the CO2 + H2 reaction system, enabling real-time in situ methylation with the produced methanol to form fatty acid methyl esters (R–COOH + CH3OH → R–COOCH3 + H2O) [10]. By coupling the hydrogenation of CO2 and the methyl esterification processes, the chemical equilibrium can be promoted, facilitating efficient CO2 conversion under milder conditions [11]. Reports have indicated that hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, combined with the introduction of fatty acids using a homogeneous Ru complex catalyst, achieved 100 % CO2 conversion at 160 °C over 24 h. However, this process suffers from a long reaction time (20–24 h) and challenges in recovering and reusing the homogeneous catalyst. Moreover, the significant steric hindrance of the Ru complex limits the activation of the resulting methyl esters into fatty alcohols in the presence of H2. In heterogeneous catalytic systems, the introduction of CO2 into the hydrogenation of fatty acids has shown to enhance selectivity towards CnH2n+2 alkanes rather than fatty alcohols at high temperature, as reported by Chung-Sung Tan et al. [12]. In this scenario, CO2 was primarily utilized as a solvent to improve mass transfer during the catalytic reaction [13]. Moreover, when a certain amount of CO2 is present at the start of the reaction, it can effectively inhibit the decarbonylation side reaction that leads to the formation of Cn−1 alkanes, in accordance with Le Chatelier’s principle. This presence of CO2 promotes the hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters to produce fatty alcohols. Therefore, we propose a novel approach that integrates CO2 hydrogenation, fatty acid methyl esterification, and fatty acid methyl ester hydrogenation in a one-pot tandem catalysis process (termed CO2 hydrogenation—methyl esterification—methyl ester hydrogenation). This method not only enhances the positive improvement of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol but also eliminates the cumbersome additional steps required for methyl esterification before fatty acid hydrogenation. Ultimately, this strategy improves the reaction selectivity from fatty acid methyl esters to fatty alcohols via fatty aldehyde intermediates. The real-time coupling reaction of CO2 hydrogenation, methyl esterification, and methyl ester hydrogenation can simultaneously generate high-value products such as methanol and fatty alcohols, representing a novel type of tandem reaction (Fig. 2 ). This approach also optimizes the high-value utilization of both CO2 and fatty acids. However, implementing this new reaction poses significant challenges; it requires that the reaction conditions be compatible across all three individual reactions while ensuring that the catalyst’s active sites effectively facilitate the adsorption and activation of the reactant molecules. 1) CO2 + 5H2 + R-COOH → CH3OH + R–CH2OH + H2O(Total reaction equation In this work, we considered that the transition metal catalyst Cu/ZrO2 has been reported to be effective for both CO2 hydrogenation [14] and fatty acid/methyl ester hydrogenation [15], while ZnO/ZrO2 is Lewis acid sites [16], which facilitates the methyl esterification reaction [17]. Considering that hydrophobic carbon support has the resistance of water and doping N can cause lattice distortion and increase the defect site of carbon, which can promote the adsorption and dissociation of carbonyl hydrogenation as demonstrated in the hydrogenation of palmitic acid to fatty alcohols using Ru/graphene catalyst [18]. Accordingly, we fabricated a CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst, which incorporates metallic Cu and Lewis acid sites, aiming to facilitate the coupling hydrogenation of CO2 and stearic acid in a one-pot tandem catalytic reaction. This approach is expected to significantly enhance the yields of both methanol and fatty alcohol, thereby overcoming thermodynamic limitations through dual promotion of the reactions. Our results demonstrated that the presence of CO2 in the fatty acid hydrogenation reaction led to an increased yield of fatty alcohol. Correspondingly, the introduction of fatty acid into the CO2 hydrogenation reaction significantly improved methanol yield. The reaction mechanism indicated that CO2 was converted to methanol, which was then consumed in situ by the fatty acid methyl esterification reaction, thereby enhancing the yield of CO2 hydrogenation by shifting the reaction to its right side. Simultaneously, the methyl ester produced through fatty acid methyl esterification was readily hydrogenated into fatty alcohol, further boosting the overall yield of fatty alcohol. The catalyst displays a high catalytic performance alongside with high resistance toward metal leaching during the hydrothermal process. Spent catalyst can be efficiently recovered by mild thermal treatment. 2 Experimental 2.1 CuZnZrOx /C–N catalyst preparation The C-N support was prepared following our previously established methodology [19]. Specifically, 4.374 g of citric acid and 10 g of (NH4)2CO3 were dissolved in 50 mL of ultrapure water. Subsequently, 2.4 g of silica and 5 mL of a 0.715 M ZnCl2 solution were added to the mixture under vigorous agitation. After stirring for 30 min in a water bath at 80 °C, the mixture was transferred to an oven and dried at 110 °C overnight. The dried solid was then ground into a fine powder and heated to 900 °C for 2 h in an Ar atmosphere at a rate of 5 °C/min to yield a black powdery sample. The resulting solid was suspended in 120 mL of a 2 M NaOH solution and stirred at 80 °C for 2 h to remove the silica template. Finally, the C-N solid powder was collected after a series of washing, filtering, and drying steps. CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts with varying zirconium loadings, while maintaining a fixed Cu/Zn molar ratio of 5:2 [20], were synthesized using the ammonia evaporation method (AE). Copper (II) nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2·3H2O), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6H2O), and zirconium(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O) were dissolved in 20 mL of ultrapure water to create a 1 M clear solution. An ammonia water solution (5 wt%) was then added dropwise to the above mixture under continuous stirring, while maintaining the pH at 7–8. The suspension was aged at room temperature for 1 h. Subsequently, the prepared C-N support was added to the solution, which was then heated to 80 °C for 2 h. The resulting suspension was filtered, followed by several water washing procedures. The obtained powder was dried overnight under vacuum at 60 °C, then ground and heated to 450 °C for 3 h in an Ar atmosphere. Finally, the CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts were reduced at 300 °C for 3 h with a temperature increase rate of 5 °C/min in a 5 % H2/Ar atmosphere. The obtained catalysts were denoted as CuZnZrOx/C-N with different mole ratio of Zn/Zr = 1/1, 1/2, 1/3, 1/4. For example, CuZn2ZrOx/C-N represented the mole ratio of Zn/Zr = 1/2. 2.2 Evaluation of the catalytic performance The catalytic hydrogenation of the feedstock was conducted in a 100 mL autoclave at a target reaction temperature for 6 h, with a stirring speed of 600 rpm. The autogenous pressure is approximately 3 MPa. The product was collected hourly during the reaction and filtered using a disposable filter. Upon completion of the reaction, the autoclave was allowed to cool automatically to room temperature. The catalyst was then centrifuged and washed with ethanol and water at room temperature before being placed overnight in a vacuum drying oven at 60 °C in preparation for the next cycle. The product analysis was conducted using a gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC–MS-QP2010 Plus, Shimadzu, with a WONDA CAP WAX column) and a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC Smart, equipped with a WONDA CAP WAX column, 30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) with a hydrogen flame ionization detector (FID). Quantitative analyses of the reactants and products were performed based on an established standard curve. High-purity N2 was utilized as the carrier gas for the GC analysis. Using stearic acid as a model fatty acid, the conversion of stearic acid and the yield of products were calculated by: (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = 1 - mole of remaining fatty acid mole of initial fatty acid × 100 % # (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = mole of each product mole of initial fatty acid - mole of remaining fatty acid × 100 % # (3) Y i e l d ( % ) = mole of each product mole of initial fatty acid × 100 % # (4) p r o d u c t i v i t y mmol C 18 O H ∙ g cat -1 ∙ h -1 = mole of C 18 O H m cat × t i m e # (5) p r o d u c t i v i t y mmol C H 3 OH ∙ g cat -1 ∙ h -1 = mole of methanol m cat × t i m e # (6) p r o d u c t i v i t y mmo l methyl stearate ∙ g cat -1 ∙ h -1 = mole of methyl stearate m cat × t i m e # 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area (SSA), pore volume, and average pore size of the catalysts were determined through nitrogen adsorption–desorption measurements at 77 K (liquid nitrogen temperature) using a JK-B112 device from Beijing Jingwei Gaobo Instrument Co. Prior to the nitrogen adsorption experiments, the samples were outgassed at 105 °C for 3 h to desorb impurities and moisture. The microstructure of the prepared catalysts was characterized via scanning electron microscopy (SEM, SEM3200) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 apparatus). Scanning transmission electron microscopy with electron energy loss spectroscopy (STEM-EELS) images was obtained using a JEOL ARM200F equipped with a CEOS probe corrector. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using an XD3 Advanced diffractometer, equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (1.54178 nm), operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The data were collected in continuous mode over a 2θ range from 5° to 80° at a scanning speed of 2°/min. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo Escalab 250Xi spectrometer using an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6 eV). A binding energy of 284.8 eV from C 1 s spectra served as the calibration standard for spectral analysis. Data fitting was performed using Avantage 5.984 software. Diffuse reflectance Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) measurements were conducted using a Frontier FT-IR spectrometer (PerkinElmer) equipped with a MIR detector. The catalyst was impregnated in 20 mL of 0.05 M stearic acid, using n-hexane as the solvent, at room temperature for 12 h. Following this, the catalyst was washed with n-hexane and dried at 80 °C overnight. For the measurements, the KBr tableting method was employed. A mixture of 120 mg of dried KBr and 1 mg of the catalyst was ground into a fine powder using a mortar, then pressed into thin flakes using a hydraulic tablet press (under a pressure of 10–15 MPa). FT-IR spectra were recorded over the range of 4000–400 cm−1 with 32 scans, using KBr thin sections as the background spectrum. The data were processed using OMNIC software. Ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were conducted using an AutoChem II 2920 instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). A sample of 100 mg of each catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h, with a temperature ramping rate of 10 °C/min in a He atmosphere flowing at 30 mL/min. After that, the catalyst was cooled down to 50 °C, where it was exposed to NH3 for 1 h at the same flow rate (30 mL/min). Following the adsorption period, the He flow was switched to purge the catalyst surface for 1 h, ensuring the removal of physically adsorbed NH3 until the measured baseline stabilized. Finally, the catalyst was heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min while maintaining a He flow of 30 mL/min. The fresh and used-1st catalysts were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis using a DTG-60 simultaneous differential thermal and thermogravimetric analyzer. Samples weighing 3–5 mg were tested under a nitrogen atmosphere with a flow rate of 30–50 mL·min−1 and heated at a rate of 10°C·min−1 up to 900 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Observation of coupling hydrogenation effects of CO2 and stearic acid over CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst Initially, we synthesized the C-N supported CuZnZrOx catalyst, which provides bi-functional function. The highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles serve as the active metal sites for hydrogenation reactions [21], while the ZnZrOx mixed oxides function as Lewis acids for the esterification reaction [16]. The selective hydrogenation of the combined CO2 and stearic acid (C17COOH) into methanol and stearic alcohol (C18OH) within a single reactor using the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst proceeded as anticipated. To investigate the coupling hydrogenation effects of CO2 and C17COOH in a single reactor, the CuZn2ZrOx/C–N catalyst was evaluated both in the presence and absence of CO2 or C17COOH (Fig. 3 a). A methanol productivity rate of 0.44 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 was observed at 200 °C with a gas mixture of CO2 and H2 under 3 MPa over a 6-hour reaction period. Upon the addition of C17COOH, the methanol formation rate increased to 0.99 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, representing a twofold enhancement compared to the reaction carried out without C17COOH. These results confirm a significant promotion of CO2 hydrogenation in the presence of C17COOH, indicating the effectiveness of the bi-functional catalyst in facilitating the desired reactions by consuming one of the intermediate species, i.e. methanol. In the hydrogenation of stearic acid (C17COOH), the selectivity for stearic alcohol (C18OH) in the absence of CO2 was 89.5 %, and yield was obtained at a rate of 0.52 mmol·gcat −1·h−1. However, when CO2 was introduced into the reactor, a significant increase in selectivity for C18OH was observed, reaching 99.2 %, and the productivity increased to 0.58 mmol·gcat −1·h−1. Fig. 3(b) illustrates the product distribution versus reaction time during the conversion of C17COOH in the presence of CO2 and H2. The primary products were stearic alcohol and methanol, with less than 1 % of C18 alkanes detected as by-products on the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst. Notably, the concentration of the detected intermediate methyl stearate increased during the initial hours, followed by a subsequent decline throughout the reaction process. This behavior suggests that C18OH and methanol were produced through the catalytic hydrogenation of methyl stearate. To further confirm the enhancement of C18OH selectivity consecutive to the presence of CO2, we conducted a reaction using methanol (at a rate of 0.44 mmol·gcat −1·h−1) to replace CO2, equivalent to the amount produced in the CO2 + H2 feed. Under these conditions, the selectivity for C18OH decreased to 68.2 % (as shown in Fig. 3a), indicating that the pathway for the hydrogenation reaction into C18OH was suppressed. Overall, while the presence of CO2 significantly enhanced C18OH selectivity, the conversion of C17COOH remained relatively unchanged, nearing a maximum conversion of 98.9 %. To further assess the coupling hydrogenation effects between C17COOH and CO2, we reduced the catalyst mass to 30 mg and replaced CO2 with Ar in the reaction feed. Under these conditions, both C17COOH conversion and C18OH selectivity were notably low, at 39.8 % and 60.9 %, respectively. However, when CO2 was re-introduced to the feed, the catalytic performance significantly improved, with C17COOH conversion increasing to 75.4 % and C18OH selectivity reaching 81.9 %. Additionally, a larger quantity of methyl stearate was produced (Fig. S1). These results further support the conclusion that in the presence of CO2, C17COOH is converted into C18OH through a reaction pathway involving the intermediate methyl stearate, which is thermodynamically more favorable for hydrogenation than the carboxylic acid groups [22]. Thus, the coupling hydrogenation effects between C17COOH and CO2 significantly boost the yields of both methanol and C18OH. 3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions for the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2 over CuZn2ZrOx/C–N To investigate whether the target coupling reaction of (CO2 + C17COOH + H2) improved upon the decoupled reactions of CO2 + H2 and C17COOH + H2, we first examined the effects of the partial pressure ratio (CO2/H2) at 200 °C for 6 h using an initial total pressure of 3 MPa and 0.03 g of catalyst. According to the coupling reaction equation: CO2 + 5H2 + C17COOH → CH3OH + C18OH + H2O, the theoretical partial pressure ratio of CO2/H2 should be 1/5. However, under this ratio, as depicted in Fig. 4 a, the yield of C18OH and the productivity of CH3OH in the coupling reaction were lower than those observed in the decoupled reactions. When the CO2/H2 ratio was increased to 1/2 and 1/4, the conversion of C17COOH remained similar. However, the selectivity for C18OH in the coupling reaction was significantly higher than in the decoupled reactions, indicating that the increased concentration of CO2 positively influenced the C17COOH + H2 reaction. Surprisingly, the amount of CH3OH generated in the coupling reaction was lower than that produced in the decoupled reaction of CO2 + H2. As the partial pressure of CO2/H2 was modified to 1/3, shown in Fig. 4(c), the coupling reaction demonstrated a superior yield for stearic alcohol and a significantly higher methanol equivalent productivity compared to the decoupled reactions, thus this partial pressure represented the optimal ratio for methanol synthesis. It is worthy to note that the amount of CH3OH produced in a decoupled reaction is lower compared to those obtained at lower PCO2/PH2 (Fig. 4c). It could be possible that at low PCO2/PH2 ratio the methanol is formed in large amount and could lower the reactivity of the second process, possible through competitive adsorption, leading to a lower conversion of C17COOH into C18OH. Overall, these results indicate that CO2 concentration plays a crucial role in the coupling reaction. The optimal performance for the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2 was achieved at a CO2/H2 ratio of 1/3. Furthermore, the reaction conditions of temperature and catalyst dosage were optimized to achieve maximum performance. As the reaction temperature increased from 180 to 200 °C, the yield of C18OH and the productivity of methanol gradually increased, indicating that higher temperatures favored the coupling reaction. However, upon further increasing the reaction temperature to 210 °C, the selectivity for C18OH slightly decreased, suggesting that the fatty alcohols underwent hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions, resulting in the formation of C18 alkanes. Given the importance of maintaining high selectivity for the target products, the reaction temperature was ultimately controlled at 200 °C, which was determined to be the optimal temperature for the catalytic hydrogenation of stearic acid to stearic alcohol. Low reaction temperature also prevents excessive metal active phase sintering according to the literature report [23]. To enhance the yields of both C18OH and methanol, the influence of catalyst loading on the catalytic performance of the coupling reaction was investigated. As shown in Fig. 4f, the yield of C18OH increased, and methanol productivity exhibited a linear increase with catalyst loading ranging from 20 to 60 mg. This trend can be attributed to an increase in the number and availability of active catalytic sites on the catalyst. However, upon further increasing the catalyst loading to 80 mg, a slight decrease in methanol productivity was observed, and the selectivity and yield of C18OH also slightly decreased. These observed trends can be ascribed that the higher catalyst loadings provided the higher number of active sites, which promoted the hydrogenation of C18OH to further form octadecane. At high catalyst loading, secondary reaction, direct HDO, could take place leading to the decrease of the C18OH. Therefore, the optimal catalyst loading for this reaction was determined to be 60 mg. 3.3 Optimization of Zr content of CuZnZrOx/C-N for the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2 In the CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst, Zr ions in the form of oxides serve as effective Lewis acid sites for the esterification reaction between C17COOH and methanol, which is a key intermediary step in the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2. Moreover, the addition of Zr is known to enhance the dispersion of Cu nanoparticles, thereby improving the catalytic performance in the CO2 + H2 hydrogenation process [24]. To modulate the yields of C18OH and methanol productivity, we adjusted the molar ratio of Zr while maintaining the same Cu/Zn mole ratio in the CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts. The concentration of the different metal loading is displayed in Table 1 . As illustrated in Fig. 5 a, the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst exhibited significantly higher productivities for C18OH and methanol, at 0.575 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 0.991 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, respectively, compared to the CuZn/C-N catalyst, which had productivities of only 0.092 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 0.586 mmol·gcat −1·h−1. The CuZn2ZrO2/C-N catalyst also outperform the other catalysts containing ZrOx, i.e. CuZn4ZrOx/C-N, and CuZn2ZrOx catalysts. These results underscore the necessity of incorporating Zr at a right amount to promote high catalytic performance for the selective hydrogenation of both CO2 and C17COOH. For better understanding the reaction mechanism, the activation energies for these catalysts have been calculated in Fig. S2 and listed in Table S1, which are 71.27 kJ/mol for the CuZn/C-N catalyst, 58.29 kJ/mol for the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst, and 79.78 kJ/mol for the CuZn4ZrOx/C-N catalyst, respectively. The CuZn2Zrx/C-N catalyst exhibited the lowest activation energy among the samples indicating the highest catalytic efficiency for the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2. The optimal catalytic performance for the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2 was achieved using the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst (Figs. 5a and b), which demonstrated the highest yield of C18OH at 98.12 % and methanol productivity of 0.99 mmol·gcat −1·h−1. To underscore the competitive performance of our methodology, we systematically compare the non-precious metal catalysts with existing systems in Table 2 . The CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst demonstrates excellent performance under relatively mild conditions (200 °C and 3 MPa), achieving the highest stearic acid conversion of 98.9 % and stearyl alcohol selectivity of 98.1 % under mild conditions. This performance is notably superior to many previously reported catalyst systems. For instance, compared to the Cu/m-ZrO2 catalyst, which operated at 300 °C and 7.5 MPa (conversion: 94.6 %, selectivity: 93.3 %) [25]. Similarly, the Co/Al2O3 catalyst required harsh conditions (300 °C and 5 MPa) to achieve a conversion of 60.0 % and a selectivity of 93.0 % [26]. It should be noted that the harsh condition easily lead to catalyst deactivation due to sintering, leaching, and phase transformation [27]. The closest catalytic performance, in terms of conversion and product selectivity, with the results presented in this study are issued from Refs. [28–31], which is obtained at higher pressure and reaction temperature. It is reported in the literature that the activity of copper-based catalysts is closely depended to the Cu NPs dispersion on the carrier [32,33], and mostly at the interface of the Cu NPs and the support [34]. However, small Cu NPs can easily aggregating to generate large particles with lower catalytic activity during the reaction when they are exposed to relatively high reaction temperatures [23]. Therefore, our CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst exhibits good catalytic performance advantages in high conversion and high yield under mild conditions, i.e. reaction temperature at ca. 200 °C, which could significantly limit the deactivation through active sites sintering. Furthermore, the detection of methyl stearate as an intermediate in the GC-FID spectra (Fig. S3) on the Zr-promoted catalysts further supports the conclusion that C17COOH is converted through esterification followed by the hydrogenation of methyl stearate into C18OH in the presence of H2. 3.4 Characterization results of the CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts The optimal CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst possesses actual loadings of 20.03 % Cu, 6.27 % Zn, and 5.03 % Zr, as determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis (Table 1). The textural properties of the investigated catalysts were quantified by N2 adsorption–desorption curves (Fig. S4a). All CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts demonstrated type IV adsorption isotherms, indicating the presence of mesoporous structures with pore sizes ranging from 2 to 50 nm. The pore size distribution further revealed that the prepared CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts exhibited a hierarchical pore structure featuring both micropores and mesopores (Fig. S4b). Table 1 summarizes the different metal content, specific surface area, pore volume, and pore diameter for the various CuZnZrOx/C-N catalysts. The SSA of the C-N support is 332 m2/g, with an average pore diameter of approximately 10.5 nm. In comparison, the specific surface areas for CuZn2ZrOx/C-N, CuZn4ZrOx/C-N, and CuZn/C-N were found to be 382 m2/g, 337 m2/g, and 452 m2/g, respectively. This indicates an increase in SSA following metal loading. However, excessive addition of Zr can lead to the formation of some ZrO2 phase (see discussion below), which in turn results in a decrease in the SSA of the catalyst. This observation is consistent with the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) results. The influence of introducing Zr components on the crystal phases of Cu and Zn was examined through X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. The CuZn/C-N catalyst primarily exhibited metallic Cu and ZnO crystal phases. Conversely, the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst displayed new characteristic peaks at 2θ = 35.5° and 38.8°, corresponding to the monoclinic CuO crystal planes, which relate to the (002) and (111) reflections, respectively. Among them, the monoclinic CuO structure is easily converted to Cu0 during the hydrogenation process, which further improves the hydrogenation of bio-oil components [37]. Characteristic diffraction peaks of hexagonal phase ZnO were observed in all catalysts with varying levels of Zr addition; however, the peak intensity was significantly lower compared to that in the CuZn/C-N catalysts. This reduction in intensity was attributed to the incorporation of Zr species into the ZnO lattice, which promotes a strong interaction between ZnO and ZrO2. This interaction favors the high dispersion of ZnO and contributes to the formation of a ZnZrOx solid solution [38]. Furthermore, the absence of diffraction peaks corresponding to ZrO2 confirms that ZrO2 is well dispersed throughout the catalysts and has formed a solid solution with the ZnO components. However, as depicted before the SSA of the CuZn4ZrOx/C-N with higher ZrO2 content, 9.6 wt%, faces decreasing value compared to that of the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N with lower ZrO2 content, 5.0 wt%. Such results could be attributed to the formation of some amorphous bulk ZrOx phase (not accurately detected by XRD), which could encapsulate the active phase, leading to the decrease of the SSA, and also to the catalytic performance as depicted in Figs. 5a and b. Such results clearly confirm the important role of the ZnZrOx solid solution on the maintaining of the Cu active sites exposure in the process. Notably, the addition of Zr resulted in a decrease in the particle size of metallic Cu, as indicated in Table 1, indicating that Zr enhances the dispersion of Cu particles. It is well-known that the interaction between Cu nanoparticles (NPs) and ZrO2 leads to a significant reduction of the Cu particle size [39]. In this study, it seems that the dispersion of Cu NPs is closely depending to the presence of a ZnZrOx solid solution. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (Fig. S5) revealed that the prepared catalysts possess a three-dimensional porous structure, characterized by particles that are randomly stacked on the surface or encapsulated within the pore channels. As the content of Zr increased, the metal oxides gradually aggregated into larger particles. This aggregation of CuZnZrOx particles facilitated the formation of interparticle pores. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images clearly identified the lattice fringe distances of 0.208 nm, 0.281 nm, 0.260 nm, 0.253 nm and 0.232 nm are ascribed to the interplanar spacing of Cu (111), ZnO (100), ZnO (002), CuO (002) and CuO (111) solid solution nanoparticles, as evidenced by their distinct lattice spacings shown in Figs. 7 (a) and (b). Noticeably, the lattice fringe distance of 0.286 nm is attributed to Zr-ZnO [40]. Although characteristic peaks of ZrO2 were not evident in the XRD patterns and HRTEM images, literature suggests that the observed lattice fringes of 0.266 nm and 0.286 nm, which are larger than those of ZnO (0.260 nm and 0.281 nm), can be attributed to Zr doping within the ZnO lattice, thus forming a Zr-ZnOx solid solution [41]. Moreover, the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst particles were characterized by CuO/Zr-ZnOx and Cu/ZnO grain boundaries. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) image and corresponding elemental mapping of the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N sample, depicted in Figs. 7C-C6, illustrated that Zr-ZnOx particles surround the CuO nanoparticles leading to the formation of CuO/Zr-ZnO grain boundaries. Additionally, the elemental mapping confirmed the uniform distribution of Zn and Zr metal oxide particles within the carbon matrix of the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst, ensuring optimal interactions and performance during the catalytic processes. The surface chemical states of the metal components in the representative CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The Zn 2p XPS spectrum in Fig. 8 a revealed characteristic peaks at binding energies of 1045 eV and 1022 eV, corresponding to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2 [42], respectively, confirming the presence of Zn2+ in all catalysts. The XPS spectrum for Zr 3d in Fig. S6 exhibited two prominent peaks at 184 eV and 182 eV, aligned with Zr 3d5/2 and Zr 3d3/2, indicating that Zr4+ is the predominant oxidation state present in the catalyst [36]. As illustrated in Fig. 8b, two main doublet peaks were observed at approximately 953.0 eV and 933.0 eV, attributed to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 [43]. In the Cu 2p3/2 spectrum, binding energies within the range of 941–944 eV were associated with electron transfer between O 2p and Cu 3d orbitals, indicating the presence of Cu2+ species across all catalysts. For instance, the CuZn/C-N catalyst exhibited Cu 2p3/2 binding energies of approximately 933.45 eV, corresponding to Cu0 or Cu+ and 935.13 eV (attributed to Cu2+) [44]. Cu LMM Auger was carried out to clarify copper specification whether it is Cu+ or Cu0. As shown in Fig. 8c, the three broad peaks at around 569.1 eV, 567.5 eV, and 570.5 eV corresponded to Cu2+, Cu0, and Cu+ species, respectively [45,46]. The three catalysts CuZn/C–N, CuZn2ZrOx/C–N, and CuZn4ZrOx/C–N exhibited relatively high Cu2+ contents in Table S2, indicating that Cu in the CuZn2ZrOx/C–N catalyst predominantly exists as Cu2+ species on the catalyst surface, which is consistent with the result of XRD. This transformation of low-valent copper species on the catalyst surface into high-valent metal oxides may occur as a result of their interaction with oxygen [47]. Specifically, CuZn/C–N had a Cu2+ content of 41.01 % and a Cu0/Cu+ ratio of 1.40. Upon the addition of Zr, CuZn2ZrOx/C–N showed the highest Cu2+ content (66.56 %) with a Cu0/Cu+ ratio of 1.03. With further addition of Zr, the Cu0/Cu+ ratio decreased to 0.92 for CuZn2ZrOx/C–N catalyst. Previous studies have shown that the coexistence of Cu0 and Cu+ is beneficial for the synergistic catalysis of fatty methyl ester [48,49] and CO2 hydrogenation [50,51]. The XPS spectra of the O 1 s signal for the different catalysts are presented in Fig. 8d. According to previous literature, the main O 1 s peaks observed at binding energies of 529.8 eV, 531.6 eV, and 532.9 eV correspond to lattice oxygen in metal oxides (denoted as Oα), surface-adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ), and oxygen species present in hydroxides (denoted as Oγ), respectively. The presence of surface-adsorbed oxygen is prone to indicative of oxygen vacancies [52]. The estimated relative concentrations of surface oxygen vacancies (Oβ) are summarized in Table S2. Compared to the CuZn/C-N catalyst, the content of Oβ significantly increased with the addition of Zr, confirming the synergistic interaction among the Cu, Zn, and Zr oxides, which enhances the density of surface oxygen defects in the catalyst. Notably, the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst exhibited the highest Oβ content at 61.42 % (Table S2), suggesting the presence of the most substantial number of oxygen vacancies. Surface oxygen vacancies are essential for CO2 hydrogenation reactions, as they facilitate the adsorption, activation, and stabilization of reaction intermediates [53]. Additionally, an increased number of oxygen vacancies promotes the adsorption of carbonyl oxygen atoms from –COOH functional groups, resulting in enhanced catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of C=O bonds [54]. To evaluate the surface acidity of the catalysts, including the distribution of acid sites and the total acid amount, ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) measurements were performed. The ammonia desorption curve, shown in Fig. 9 (a), can be divided into three distinct regions: 50–250 °C, 250–400 °C, and 400–500 °C, which correspond to weak, medium, and strong acid sites, respectively. All the catalysts demonstrated multiple acid sites. The CuZn/C-N catalyst was primarily composed of weak and medium acid sites. Notably, the spectra exhibited significant variation with the amount of added Zr. In the Zr-containing catalysts, the NH3 desorption temperature for weak acid sites was observed to be lower compared to that of the CuZn/C-N catalyst, indicating that the weak acid centers in CuZn/C-N are stronger. Furthermore, the introduction of Zr resulted in an increase in the number of strong acid sites, suggesting that the addition of Zr expands the acidic profile of the catalyst. To gain deeper insights into the acid sites present on the prepared catalysts, a quantitative analysis of the acid sites was conducted using NH3-TPD spectra. The total acid amount for the CuZn/C–N catalyst was measured at 0.455 mmol NH3/g. However, upon the introduction of Zr, the total surface acid amount significantly decreased, with values dropping to 0.192 and 0.212 mmol NH3/g for the CuZn2ZrOx/C–N and CuZn4ZrOx/C–N catalysts, respectively. Among the catalysts studied, CuZn2ZrOx/C–N exhibited the highest proportion of weak acid sites (68.23 %) and a lower content of strong acid sites, which are particularly crucial for the production of fatty alcohols. In previous studies, such as that conducted by Xu et al. [55], Lewis acids were identified as the active centers for carbonyl activation during aldehyde hydrogenation to alcohols. Therefore, the addition of appropriate amount of Zr components enhances the quantity of Lewis acid sites, thus favoring the production of fatty alcohols. It is important to note that an excessive amount of Zr in the CuZn4ZrOx/C–N catalyst resulted in an increase in the strong acid content to 24.53 %. However, in the context of fatty acid hydrogenation, these strong acid sites can inadvertently catalyze the dehydration of fatty alcohols to form alkanes [56], consequently decreasing the selectivity for fatty alcohols. This finding correlates with the observed higher catalytic selectivity for the C18 alkane in Fig. 5a. Overall, the introduction of Zr serves to modulate both the strength and quantity of acid sites on the catalysts. A relatively higher proportion of Lewis acid sites, along with a broader variety of acid sites, can be more beneficial for the CuZnZrOx/C–N-catalyzed coupling hydrogenation of stearic acid to alcohols. Among the catalysts evaluated, CuZn2ZrOx/C–N displayed a diverse spectrum of acid sites, including weak, medium, and strong acid sites, while simultaneously exhibiting a lower amount of strong acid sites. This profile effectively explains its superior catalytic activity and selectivity in the targeted reactions. 3.5 Tracking the process of coupling reaction over CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst To verify the hypothesis that stearic alcohol can be generated from stearic acid methyl ester through the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH with CO2, we employed gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) to monitor the progress of the coupling reaction over the CuZn2ZrOx/C–N catalyst. The results are depicted in Fig. 10 . As the reaction time progressed, the production of the target product, stearic alcohol (C18OH, increased significantly. Notably, even at the initial stages of the reaction, small amounts of stearic acid methyl ester (C17COOCH3) and stearic aldehyde (C17CHO) were detected. At 3 h, a substantial concentration of C17COOCH3 was observed, which then gradually decreased as the reaction continued. These findings provide strong evidence supporting the hypothesis that stearic acid can be converted into stearic acid methyl ester as an intermediate under a mixed atmosphere of CO2 and H2, followed by subsequent hydrogenation to form stearic alcohol. In-situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFT) was further employed to monitor the catalytic process during the methanol production from CO2 and H2 over the CuZnZrOx/C–N catalyst (CO2/H2 = 1/3). Figs. 11 (a) and (b) illustrate the surface-adsorbed and intermediate species associated with this reaction. As the reaction time progressed, there was a significant intensification of the signals corresponding to two main intermediates: formate (HCOO*) and methoxy (CH3O*). Specific wavenumber bands at 1371 cm−1, 2735 cm−1, 2883 cm−1, and 2986 cm−1 were attributed to formate species, while bands at 1052 cm−1, 1143 cm−1, 2836 cm−1, and 2934 cm−1 corresponded to methoxy species. Additionally, a wavenumber at 1236 cm−1 was ascribed to the presence of bicarbonate species (HCO3*). Importantly, no by-product CO signal was detected during the reaction, indicating that the formation of CH3OH proceeded primarily via the HCOO* and CH3O* intermediate reaction pathways. It is noteworthy that the hydrogenation of the CH3O* intermediate is a relatively slow step, which helps explain why these intermediate species are readily captured in the DRIFTS spectra [57]. To investigate the reaction of fatty acids with methanol generated in a CO2/H2 mixture atmosphere, caprylic acid was introduced as a model reactant into the in situ DRIFT system while maintaining a continuous flow of the CO2/H2 mixture. As illustrated in Fig. S7, following the introduction of caprylic acid, the intermediates involved in methanol synthesis were gradually depleted; however, no new spectral bands appeared. This lack of new bands is presumed to result from the rapid desorption of products formed from the esterification of caprylic acid with methanol, which occurred too quickly to be captured in the spectra. To further explore this process, we selected methyl laurate, a compound with a higher boiling point, as a probe reactant. Figs. 11(c) and (d) depict the transformation of methyl laurate on the surface of the CuZn2ZrOx/C–N catalyst under a CO2/H2 atmosphere at a reaction temperature of 200 °C. Upon the introduction of methyl laurate vapor, the wavenumbers in the range of 2990–2850 cm−1 corresponded to the C–H stretching vibrations of the –CH3, −CH2, and –CH functional groups [58]. Additionally, the bands between 1471–1407 cm−1 were attributed to C–H bending vibrations. Furthermore, bands observed at 1240–1015 cm−1 and 1710 cm−1 were assigned to the C–O–C stretching absorption peak of the ester and the C=O stretching vibration of the carbonyl group [59], respectively, indicating the adsorption of the substrate molecules on the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst surface. After introducing the CO2/H2 gas flow at 200 °C, the peak corresponding to methyl laurate gradually decreased with increasing reaction time. At approximately 30 min of reaction time, a new peak emerged at 1630 cm−1, attributed to the C=O stretching vibration of the acyl group (RCO*). As the reaction time was extended to 40 min, the peak associated with the acyl group disappeared, while a bending vibration peak of –CH3 emerged at 1410 cm−1, and a new peak at 1075 cm−1 was observed, corresponding to the C–O stretching vibration of an alcohol [60]. These results confirm that methyl laurate underwent hydrogenation to form alcohols via the acyl intermediate pathway on the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst, illustrating the effectiveness of the catalyst in facilitating this transformation under the specified reaction conditions. 3.6 Catalytic stability of CuZnZrOx/C-N catalyst We evaluated the reusability of the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst in the coupling hydrogenation process. After each reaction cycle, the catalyst was separated and thoroughly washed three times with anhydrous ethanol to remove any adsorbed substances. The treated catalyst was then vacuum-dried overnight in preparation for the subsequent cycle. As illustrated in Figs. 12 (a) and (b), the conversion of C17COOH and the yield of C18OH during the first cycle were 80.8 % and 74.8 %, respectively. However, by the third cycle, the yield of C18OH had decreased significantly from 74.8 % to 45.4 %. Notably, during the fourth cycle, the catalytic activity for stearic acid hydrogenation was inhibited considerably, and the ability to convert CO2 to methanol was nearly lost, as evidenced by the absence of stearic acid methyl ester production. These findings highlight the critical role of stearic acid methyl ester formation and the occurrence of CO2 hydrogenation in maintaining effective catalytic performance during the coupling reaction. Several factors contribute to catalyst deactivation in heterogeneous catalysis, including the leaching of active components, aggregation and sintering of active species, structural changes, and surface carbon coverage on active sites [61]. Notably, deactivation caused by active metal leaching under hydrothermal process is often severe and irreversible [27]. Lin et al. [28] have also reported a drastic deactivation of the Co/AC and Co encapsulated inside carbon shell during the hydrothermal hydrogenation of palmitic acid consecutive to the metal leaching. The Co/AC deactivated after only one cycle test while the carbon encapsulated Co displayed a higher resistance as it only deactivated after three cycling tests. To investigate the underlying mechanisms for the observed poor stability, we first conducted leaching experiments with the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst during the coupled reaction. The catalyst was removed after 3 h of reaction, and the resulting filtrate was utilized as the reactant under identical conditions to assess further activity. As illustrated in Fig. 12(c), after the catalyst was removed, stearic acid did not continue to convert over time, and no additional stearic alcohol or stearic acid methyl ester was produced. Further metal analysis of the reaction solution was conducted using ICP-OES in Table S3. The leaching amount of Cu, Zn, and Zr are determined to be 0.0048 %, 0.0022 %, and <0.0001 %, respectively. Therefore, the leaching amounts of metals were negligible. These outcomes suggest that metal leaching from the catalyst was not responsible for the observed catalyst deactivation. Such lack of metal leaching could be attributed to the existence of strong metal-support interactions in the catalytic system as evidenced by the STEM-EELS analysis presented before. Such results are also confirmed by the fact that the deactivation only occurs after three cycling tests and not during the first one. This phenomenon could be ascribed to some pore plugging or active sites encapsulation by some solid residue during the reaction as will be discussed in detail further in the study. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) results indicated that the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst retained its porous and morphological structure even after the fifth recycling, as shown in Fig. S8. However, the XRD spectra revealed changes in the crystalline structure of the used catalyst (Fig. 12(d)). Notably, the used catalyst did not exhibit characteristic peaks of CuO; instead, new peaks appeared at 43.55°, 50.6°, and 74.2°, which were attributed to metallic Cu (PDF#99–0034). The increasing sharpness of these peaks with the number of cycles suggested sintering and aggregation of the active Cu sites, resulting in larger particle sizes. This phenomenon confirmed the gradual reduction of CuO to Cu during the reaction under high-pressure H2 conditions [62], which contributed to an increase in metal Cu particle size and, consequently, could be at the origin of the decrease in catalytic performance. FTIR spectra of the used and fresh catalysts (Fig. S9) shown that characteristic peaks for the C–H and C–C bonds in the alkyl chains are observed at approximately 2916 cm−1, 1466 cm−1, and 719 cm−1, and the C-O stretching mode of carboxylates and deformation mode of O–H were represented by peaks at 1537 cm−1 and 1400 cm−1, respectively. The spectrum provides qualitative evidence that the compounds adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst are likely to be oxygenates [26]. Additionally, the decrease in mass loss, at low region temperature, from TGA results (Fig. S10) and the decrease in BET surface area and pore volume of the spent catalysts in Table S4 further suggest the possible partial blockage of the active sites by adsorbed reactants and intermediates on the catalyst surface. Therefore, the accumulation of reactants and intermediates on the catalyst surface was likely the primary cause of the observed decrease in catalytic activity. To confirm such hypothesis and to recover the catalyst activity, we conducted thermal regeneration of the used catalyst, which involved calcination followed by reduction at 200 °C for 2 h. XRD analysis (Fig. 6, Fig. 12(d)) revealed no significant differences in crystalline diffraction peaks between the fresh catalyst and the reductively regenerated catalyst. The FTIR spectra of the regenerated sample (Fig. S9) were very similar to those of the fresh catalyst, indicating that the reductive regeneration treatment effectively removed reaction products from the catalyst surface. SEM results after regeneration showed no significant morphological changes (Fig. S11). TEM results for the regenerated catalyst displayed almost no changes of crystalline phases of the active sites (Fig. S12). We further conducted the XPS and Cu LMM Auger to check the chemical state of active site after regeneration. Fig. S13 showed the XPS spectrum results and Table S5 showed the ratio of Cu species and oxygen species. The Cu0/Cu+ ratios of the fresh and regenerated catalysts were close (1.03 and 0.88, respectively), indicating that the active site content of the catalysts affected little. The surface-adsorbed oxygen (denoted as Oβ) content of the fresh and regenerated catalysts is 61.42 % and 60.3 %, respectively, suggesting that regeneration does not affect the Oβ content of the catalysts. Therefore, the surface composition of the catalysts were not affected by the regeneration process. The regenerated catalyst was further evaluated in the process, with regeneration between each cycle, and confirms that active sites fouling is the main cause for deactivation (Fig. 12(e, f)). The selectivity for stearic alcohol remained above 85 %. The conversion of stearic acid and the yield of stearic alcohol decreased only marginally by approximately 7 % (from 82.1 % to 75.4 %) and 10 % (from 75.3 % to 64.8 %), respectively. The observed results also phase out the possible contribution of the Cu NPs sintering in the deactivation process as expected above. In addition, according to the results depicted in Fig. 12a, the activity declines after three cycles and thus, regeneration could be done not between each cycle, as depicted in Fig. 12e, but after three cycles to maintain the accessibility of the active site. This indicates that the catalyst can be reused without significant loss of activity, demonstrating good catalytic stability after regeneration. Indeed, it has been reported by Lin et al. [28] that Co/AC catalyst displayed a high deactivation rate during the hydrothermal hydrogenation of palmitic acid consecutive to metal leaching, while such phenomenon has not been occurred in our work, which highlighted the significant improvement of the developed catalyst. Work is ongoing to improve the resistance again fouling to reduce the frequency of regeneration step by increasing the operational pressure, >3 MPa, or by evaluating the catalyst at slightly higher reaction temperature, i.e. ≥210 °C. 3.7 Discussion In this study, we successfully executed a novel tandem catalytic reaction that couples CO2 with fatty acid hydrogenation to produce methanol and fatty alcohol. This process encompasses a three-step tandem sequence: CO2 hydrogenation, methyl esterification, and methyl ester hydrogenation. Each step involves distinct target products and reaction mechanisms. Moreover, the types, spacing, and spatial distribution of the active sites on the catalyst are influenced by the size of the substrate molecules, as well as by the processes of mass transfer and diffusion. Synchronizing the three reaction rates for CO2 hydrogenation, methyl esterification, and methyl ester hydrogenation within the same catalyst under identical reaction conditions presents significant challenges. Achieving this synchronization is crucial for maximizing the efficiency and yield of the desired products in this tandem catalytic process. Inspired by the principles of relay catalytic systems in coupling reactions [63–70], we designed specific intermediates and reaction pathways tailored to achieve the target products, guiding the reactions to proceed sequentially towards the desired outcomes. In pursuit of this design, we aimed at constructing C-N supported CuZnZrOx catalysts with bi-functional sites and hierarchical pore structure via deposition–precipitation, utilizing ammonia as the precipitant. The characterized catalysts by BET verified hierarchical pore structures featuring both micropores and mesopores, which facilitate the spatial selection transformation of the target reactants. Specifically, smaller molecules with a kinetic diameter of less than 2 nm, such as CO2 and H2 were able to diffuse and transport effectively within the micropores, while larger molecules with kinetic diameters exceeding 2 nm, such as fatty acids, predominantly diffused and transported through the mesopores. The optimized CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst provided bi-functional sites for catalyzing hydrogenation and esterification. The first site consisted of metallic Cu in the form of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles as shown by XRD and HRTEM results, serving as the metal sites for the dissociation of H2 into H atoms. The second site comprised ZnZrOx mixed oxides with abundance of oxygen vacancies that functioned as Lewis acids for activating CO2 and carbonyl ligand (C=O) from –COOH of stearic acid. It is known to us, in the decoupling reaction of CO2 hydrogenation, the adsorbed CO2 is hydrogenated to methanol and by-product CO at the interface between copper particles and ZnZrOx composite oxides [71]. In the decoupling reaction of C17COOH hydrogenation, the adsorbed C17COOH is hydrogenated to C18OH at the interface between copper particles and ZnZrOx complex oxides [72], or deeply hydrogenated as by-products alkanes [73,74] and CO2 in the form of decarboxylation route [75,76]. In the coupling of CO2 hydrogenation—methyl esterification—methyl ester hydrogenation reaction (Fig. 13 ), the methanol is still produced at the same catalytic site as that in the decoupling CO2 hydrogenation, however, the difference is that in this tandem process, methanol is immediately consumed by C17COOH at the ZnZrOx Lewis sites via methyl esterification reaction, resulting in C17COOCH3 intermediates, which promotes the movement of CO2 hydrogenation towards the direction of methanol product. Immediately after, the generated C17COOCH3 intermediate was in situ hydrogenated at the interface between the copper particles and the ZnZrOx complex oxides, which can eliminate the influence of the external diffusion of C17COOCH3 on the catalyst surface, and thus accelerated the reaction rate of C17COOCH3 hydrogenation to fatty alcohol C18OH and methanol. Therefore, the final methanol yield in the coupling hydrogenation was much higher than that of decoupling CO2 hydrogenation as seen in Fig. 3a. Comparison of hydrogenation reaction results with only methanol introduced into stearic acid, the yield of C18OH fatty alcohol was lower than that of with introduction of CO2, although there is the presence of C17COOCH3 intermediate via methyl esterification in Fig. 3a. On the other hand, it is known that for the single hydrogenation of C17COOCH3, there are by products CO2 and Cn−1 alkanes via the decarbonylation side reaction. Out results indicated that the presence of CO2 at the start of the reaction, can effectively inhibit the decarbonylation side reaction, good consistent with Le Chatelier’s principle, and thus largely promote the hydrogenation of fatty acid methyl esters to produce fatty alcohols instead of byproduct Cn−1 alkanes. 4 Conclusions In summary, the hydrogenation of fatty acid (C17COOH) over the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst can be significantly enhanced by coupling with CO2, leading to a notable increase in the selectivity for fatty alcohol (C18OH). Under the optimized reaction conditions—specifically, a CO2 to H2 ratio of 1:3 at 200 °C for 6 h-methanol productivity reached 0.99 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and C18OH productivity achieved 0.575 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, with selectivity exceeding 99 %. The optimization of Zr addition facilitated the formation of a ZnZrOx solid solution, which contributed to the creation of highly dispersed Cu species and a broader array of acid sites with a favorable medium acid concentration. These enhancements collectively promote the coupling hydrogenation of C17COOH and CO2. In situ DRIFT spectroscopy and GC–MS analyses indicated that C17COOH undergoes conversion via the intermediate C17COOCH3 in a mixed atmosphere of CO2 and H2, subsequently leading to hydrogenation into stearic alcohol on the CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst. This coupling reaction provides significant insights into the simultaneous utilization of CO2 and biomass-derived fatty acids for the production of value-added chemicals. Our findings may inspire the design of more synergistically coupled catalytic reactions that leverage dual-promotional effects for the hydrogenation of both CO2 and –COOH compounds. The as-synthesized catalyst also displays high resistance toward leaching problem compared to other catalysts used for fatty acid hydrogenation in the literature thanks to the high metal-support interactions. However, deactivation still occurs after few cycles, which is mostly due to the catalyst surface fouling by the intermediate species. The deactivated catalyst can be efficiently regenerated by a mild thermal treatment. coredata.dc:description: The hydrogenation of fatty acids to fatty alcohols, alongside the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, represents crucial pathways for addressing the depletion of fossil resources and achieving carbon neutrality. However, the catalytic conversion rates of these two reactions remain low under mild conditions. In this study, we discovered an innovative approach that couples stearic acid (C17COOH) hydrogenation with CO2 hydrogenation in a one-pot catalytic tandem process using the optimized CuZn2ZrOx/C-N catalyst. This method significantly enhances the yields of methanol and fatty alcohol under mild reaction conditions of 200 °C, 3 MPa, 6 h, with a H2:CO2 ratio of 3:1. The reaction mechanism revealed that stearic acid methyl ester (C17COOCH3) acts as a key intermediate in the coupling process. Specifically, the in situ methanol produced from CO2 hydrogenation is converted by C17COOH into C17COOCH3, which is then hydrogenated to form stearic alcohol. This coupling reaction offers important insights for the simultaneous utilization of CO2 and biomass-derived fatty acids in producing value-added chemicals. Furthermore, our findings could inspire the design of more synergistically coupled catalytic reactions that leverage dual-promotional effects for the hydrogenation of CO2 and carboxylic acid compounds. This approach not only enhances the efficiency of these transformations but also aligns with the broader goals of sustainability and resource efficiency in chemical processes.
